sources: Hörst Training for Climbing 3rd ed — weighted pullup protocol

updates.description: Free-form technique drill session at the gym: silent feet, no readjust, hip engagement, breathing control. Grade kept well below max to allow movement quality focus.
cues: Silent feet: place feet without sound, feel the hold before weighting
No readjust: commit to each foot placement first time
Hip engagement: actively twist hips toward wall on steep terrain
Breathing: exhale on hard moves, never hold breath
Grade should feel easy — this is skill work, not fitness work

updates.description: Bulgarian or rear-foot-elevated split squat. Unilateral lower body strength targeting quad, glute, and hip stability — directly transfers to high-stepping and heel hook loading. One of the few lower body exercises consistently recommended across climbing coaches.
cues: Back foot elevated on bench or box at knee height
Front foot far enough forward that shin stays vertical at bottom
Knee tracks over second toe throughout — no valgus collapse
Torso upright or slight forward lean, core engaged
Full range: back knee approaches but does not touch floor
3-second eccentric lower for maximum tendon adaptation

updates.description: Supinated-grip pull-up (palms toward face). Targets biceps and lats with strong forearm flexor involvement. Higher biceps activation than pronated pullup, making it a useful complement for climbers who lack elbow flexor strength relative to lat strength.
cues: Shoulders packed before pulling: depress and retract scapulae
Initiate movement by driving elbows down toward hips, not by shrugging
Chin clearly over bar at top — no neck craning
Full extension at bottom: straight arms before each rep
3-second eccentric lower — do not drop
Quality over quantity: stop set when form breaks

updates.description: Isometric and dynamic scapular depression / retraction drill from a dead hang. Activates lower trapezius and serratus anterior without elbow flexion. Critical for shoulder health in climbers — prevents impingement, builds the foundation for all pulling movements. Hörst describes it as 'The Best Climbing Exercise You're Not Doing'.
cues: Start in dead hang: arms fully extended, shoulders passively elevated
With straight arms only: pull shoulders down and back (do NOT bend elbows)
Feel lower trapezius and lats engage — chest rises slightly toward bar
Hold 2 seconds at top, then slowly return to passive hang
Zero elbow bend throughout — if elbows bend, it has become a pullup
Do before every climbing session as part of warm-up

updates.description: Horizontal pull from below a bar or rings with body at an angle. Targets rhomboids, mid-traps, and rear deltoids — antagonist musculature to climbing's dominant vertical pull pattern. Reduces shoulder injury risk. Angle of body controls difficulty: more horizontal = harder.
cues: Body forms a straight line from heels to shoulders — engage core and glutes
Initiate by retracting scapulae before bending elbows
Pull bar or rings to lower sternum / upper abdomen — not chin
Elbows stay close to body at roughly 45° flare
Full extension at bottom before next rep
To increase difficulty: raise feet, use rings, add pause at top

updates.description: Standard pronated pullup with a resistance band looped over the bar for assistance. Removes a percentage of bodyweight to allow proper pullup mechanics for climbers not yet able to do 3+ unassisted reps. Progressive: move to thinner bands as strength builds.
cues: Knee or foot in band — knee in band = more stable, foot in band = more authentic movement
Same cues as standard pullup: packed shoulders, elbows driving down
Choose band that allows 5-8 clean reps — if 10+ feels easy, use thinner band
Eccentric still matters: control the lowering phase even with band assistance
Goal: eliminate band entirely. Transition test: can you do 3 unassisted reps?

updates.description: Standard horizontal push-up. Primary antagonist pressing movement for climbers — counterbalances the dominant pulling and internal rotation load. Targets pectorals, anterior deltoid, triceps, and serratus anterior. Accessible, zero-equipment, foundational.
cues: Hands shoulder-width or slightly wider, fingers spread and gripping the floor
Body forms a single rigid plank: core, glutes, quads all engaged
Elbows at 45° flare from torso — not flared wide, not pinned in
Lower chest to 1-2 cm from floor — full range of motion
Push floor away on the way up: protract scapulae at the top
Quality: 3-second lower. If reps degrade to half-ROM, stop the set

updates.description: Vertical push-up pattern from a pike (inverted-V) body position — hip hinge with hands and feet on floor, head below hips. Emphasises anterior deltoid and triceps more than horizontal pushup. Progression toward handstand pushup; directly trains overhead pressing strength for manteling.
cues: Start in downward-dog position: hips high, arms and legs straight
Lower crown of head toward the floor between hands
Elbows flare naturally outward — allow this in the pike position
Push back to full arm extension, maintaining hip elevation throughout
Walk feet closer to hands for more vertical load (harder); further away for easier
If wrists are uncomfortable, use push-up handles or fists

updates.description: Horizontal barbell or dumbbell pressing. Comprehensive horizontal push pattern targeting pectorals, anterior deltoid, and triceps. Most load-measurable of all pressing movements, making progressive overload easy to track. Useful for climbers needing significant upper-body push antagonist work to address strength imbalances.
cues: Feet flat on floor, slight arch in lower back — retract and depress scapulae against bench
Grip width: slightly outside shoulder width — wrists stacked over elbows at bottom
Lower bar to lower sternum with control — 3-second eccentric
Drive feet through floor and squeeze glutes on the press
Elbows at 45-75° flare — avoid flaring fully to protect shoulder
Dumbbells: allow natural arc rather than forcing a straight bar path

updates.description: Vertical pressing pattern (barbell or dumbbell). Targets anterior/medial deltoid and triceps. Trains the overhead position climbers need for manteling and high-ball pressing. Addresses the deltoid imbalance common in climbers who over-train vertical pull.
cues: Standing: feet shoulder-width, slight core brace — do not hyperextend lower back
Bar starts at upper chest / collarbone level, elbows slightly in front of bar
Press directly overhead — bar travels in a slight arc around the face
Finish with bar over mid-foot and ears visible in front of upper arm
Lower with control: 3-second eccentric
Seated dumbbell variation is shoulder-health-friendly alternative if bar feels uncomfortable

updates.description: Bent-over barbell or dumbbell horizontal row. Targets rhomboids, mid-trapezius, rear deltoid, and biceps. Heaviest loadable horizontal pull movement — effective for climbers who need significant upper-back volume to counterbalance anterior shoulder loading. Dumbbell variation is accessible and allows unilateral work.
cues: Hip hinge to ~45°: flat back, core braced, chest up
Pull bar to lower abdomen / upper hip — not chest
Lead with elbows driving back and up — do not shrug
Retract scapulae at the top: feel mid-back squeeze
3-second controlled eccentric lower — no bouncing off legs
If lower back fatigues before upper back, reduce load or switch to dumbbell single-arm row

updates.description: Push-up performed on gymnastics rings. Increased difficulty vs floor pushup: instability activates rotator cuff and serratus anterior more intensely. Rings allow natural wrist rotation through the press, reducing wrist and shoulder stress. Excellent climbing-specific antagonist work.
cues: Rings at ~30 cm from floor — adjust height to control difficulty
Grip rings with knuckles facing out at the bottom of the movement
Allow rings to rotate inward (pronation) as you press up — natural movement
Body remains a rigid plank throughout: core and glutes engaged
To regress: raise rings higher (less bodyweight). To progress: elevate feet
Pause 2 seconds at top in full support position for shoulder stability benefit

bug_fixes.reason: barbell_row has equipment_required=['weight'] — load_model must be external_load

new_exercises.name: Frenchies (Isometric Pull-up Intervals)

prescription_defaults.notes: One Frenchie = pull to top (4s hold) → lower to 90° (4s hold) → lower to 120° (4s hold) → return to dead hang. That is 1 rep. Do as many full reps as possible per set, then rest 5 min. 2-3 sets. Hörst coined term in Flash Training (1994). Stop set when unable to complete a full pull or maintain 4s hold.

new_exercises.description: Frenchies combine dynamic pull-up strength with isometric lock-offs at three joint angles (top/full lock, 90°, 120°), creating one of the most climbing-specific upper-body strength-endurance exercises available. Named and popularised by Eric Hörst (Flash Training, 1994). The time-under-tension at multiple angles directly mirrors the lock-off demands of hard bouldering and steep sport climbing. Elbow stress is significant — do not perform with existing elbow/medial epicondyle pain. Progress by adding a 4th or 5th lock-off angle per rep or by adding weight.
cues: Rep 1 protocol: pull to chin over bar → hold 4s; lower to dead hang; pull again → lower to 90° → hold 4s; lower to dead hang; pull again → lower to 120° → hold 4s; return to dead hang = 1 rep
Palms facing away (pronated) or toward you (supinated) — both valid, alternate for variety
4-second holds are non-negotiable — shorter holds reduce benefit significantly
Set ends when you can no longer do a complete pull-up OR cannot hold 4 seconds
5 full minutes rest between sets — less rest compromises quality severely
Elbow warning: if lateral or medial elbow pain during holds, stop immediately

new_exercises.name: Weighted Pull-up

prescription_defaults.notes: Add weight via harness or weight belt — not backpack. Load: choose weight where you can do 4 reps with perfect form. Prerequisite: 10 clean bodyweight pull-ups. Hörst 3 sets × 4-6 reps, 3 min rest. Start at +5 kg, increase 2.5 kg when hitting upper end of rep range.

new_exercises.description: Weighted pull-up is the primary maximum strength exercise for vertical pulling in climbing training. Adding load forces neural and structural adaptation beyond what bodyweight pull-ups can provide. Hörst consistently recommends weighted pull-ups as a companion to fingerboard training — lat and bicep strength directly limits how hard you can pull through on steep terrain. Prerequisite: 10 consecutive clean bodyweight pull-ups before adding weight. Load via climbing harness + weight plate or dedicated weight belt (not backpack — disrupts shoulder mechanics).
cues: Load via climbing harness or dip belt — weight must hang from hips, not spine
Same technique as standard pull-up: packed scapulae, elbows drive down and in
Full range: dead hang start to chin clearly over bar
3-second eccentric lower — this is where strength is built
Choose load for 4-6 clean reps. If you hit 6 cleanly twice in a row, add 2.5 kg
Do NOT do weighted pull-ups when fingers or elbows are inflamed or fatigued from climbing

new_exercises.name: Uneven-Grip Pull-up (One-Arm Progression)

prescription_defaults.notes: One hand on bar, other hand grips a sling looped over bar — hands offset 30-60 cm (start with 30 cm). 3 sets × 5 reps each arm, 3 min rest between sets. Increase offset as strength improves. Long-term progression toward one-arm pull-up. Hörst: begin with 12-inch offset, increase when you can do 5 solid reps.

new_exercises.description: Uneven-grip pull-up progressively loads one arm more than the other by offsetting hand height, bridging between two-arm pull-ups and one-arm pull-ups. Hörst recommends it as the most climbing-specific path to lock-off strength and eventual one-arm pull-up capacity. Use a sling looped over a pull-up bar — high hand on bar (palms-in or out), low hand grips sling with deep two-finger or pinch grip (more climbing-specific). Start with 30 cm offset; as strength improves increase to 60 cm. Alternate arms each set.
cues: High hand on bar, low hand on sling — not the reverse
Focus on pulling with the HIGH hand; low hand assists progressively less
Full range of motion required — dead hang to chin over bar height
Alternate arms each set: do not favour one side
30 cm offset for beginners → 45 cm → 60 cm as a rough progression
To increase climbing specificity: high hand uses palms-away (pronated) grip
